notes: Perfect claim overlap (C8, C71, C115, C136, C155) on microglia comparison between adult recovery and juvenile learning. LLM finds data sufficient despite noting sample size limitations; peer reviewers question mechanistic interpretation and request causal experiments to distinguish whether microglia contribute to degradation or recovery.

High overlap (C6, C7, C31, C57, C58, C61, C69, C70, C134) on microglia and MHC I expression findings. Both agree the data showing increased microglia and MHC I during degradation with return to baseline is solid, though LLM includes additional claims (C55, C56, C59, C60, C134) about scRNA-seq methodology.

Strong overlap (C9, C34, C125, C158) on LMAN lesion experiments. LLM finds evidence sufficient that recovery occurs without LMAN; peer reviewers express major concerns about insufficient quantitative analyses and inability to ascertain if key aspects of degradation occur in LMAN-lesioned animals. Peer review requests quantitative syntax analysis.

Good overlap (C11, C35, C130) on conclusion that adult recovery mechanisms differ from juvenile learning. Both agree recovery is LMAN-independent, representing non-canonical vocal learning. Peer review affirms this as 'convincing' though requests better quantification.

Moderate overlap (C4, C28, C29, C30, C48, C49, C67, C68) on primary behavioral findings. Both agree that silencing HVC inhibitory neurons causes song degradation followed by recovery. Reviewers describe effects as 'striking' and do not question basic behavioral findings. LLM result includes additional claims about quantitative metrics and controls.

Moderate overlap (C81, C82, C83, C84, C141) on chronic LFP findings. Both agree that LFP deflections and spectral power show dysregulation during degradation and recovery parallel to song recovery. Peer reviewer explicitly affirms these findings. LLM result includes additional claims about correlation with song quality.

Small overlap (C59, C60) on attribution of microglial changes to interneuron silencing. LLM finds control data sufficient to support causal link; peer reviewer questions whether TeNT expression itself or batch variability could drive inflammation differences, requesting additional evidence or discussion.

Minimal overlap (C56) on scRNA-seq methodology and interpretation. Both express uncertainty: LLM cites limited sample size (n=2 per condition) and lack of power analysis; peer reviewer questions interpretation of relative vs absolute abundance and statistical significance of observed reductions in cell types.

Small overlap (C56, C57, C58) on scRNA-seq cell type abundance. LLM finds microglia increase supported despite sample size limitations; peer reviewer questions how to interpret Y-axis (relative vs absolute) and whether reductions in other cell types are significant. Different focus within overlapping claims.

Small overlap (C50, C51, C52) on song recovery characterization. LLM finds acoustic analysis sufficient; peer reviewer notes recovery is based mainly on duration/interval measures but requests Markov-chain analysis of syllable sequences since HVC codes sequence, questioning whether sequences truly recovered or morphed.

Minimal overlap (C94, C95) on Neuropixel recordings showing firing rate changes. Both accept the data showing persistent neural alterations despite behavioral recovery. Peer review describes 'gross circuit-level abnormalities in HVC-RA transmission' and 'synaptic homeostasis.'

Minimal overlap (C12, C33) on altered neural dynamics. Both agree on solid evidence of persistent electrophysiological changes. LLM focuses on chronic LFP recordings; peer review affirms 'altered neural dynamics in HVC' more broadly.

Minimal overlap (C58) on transcriptomic findings. LLM finds MHC I and B2M findings supported; peer reviewer agrees but notes transcriptomic data are underexplored beyond these genes, requesting discussion of whether data support or rule out other mechanistic hypotheses.
Minimal overlap (C113) on central conclusion about behavioral recovery despite altered dynamics. Both agree this is a key finding strongly supported by the data.

Minimal overlap (C85) on increased alpha/gamma power. LLM finds data supported; peer reviewer finds increased gamma 'counterintuitive' given inhibitory neuron silencing should reduce gamma, requests interpretation of incongruent results.
Minimal overlap (C104) on alpha power findings. LLM finds spike-field coherence analysis supported; peer reviewer questions increased gamma power as counterintuitive, requesting discussion.
Minimal overlap (C112) on persistent neural changes. Both agree on evidence of permanent alterations in neural dynamics despite behavioral recovery.
Claims C14, C15, C37, C38, C164 about local homeostatic mechanisms only in LLM results. No direct peer review match, though related to R10 discussion of LMAN-independence.

Claims C32, C64, C72, C138, C139 about functional role of microglia only explicitly marked UNCERTAIN in LLM results. Peer review R5 questions mechanistic interpretation but doesn't create separate result for functional role speculation.

Claims C97, C98, C99, C144, C145, C146, C151, C152 about mechanistic models for HVC-RA dynamics and alpha power source only in LLM results. LLM appropriately marks as speculative hypotheses requiring validation.
Claims C90, C91 about seizure-like events only in LLM results. No corresponding peer review discussion identified.

Claim C40 about dlx5 promoter specificity only in peer review. Reviewer explicitly challenges targeting specificity claims, requests histological confirmation. Not separately evaluated in LLM results.
